info.title: Disputes
info.description:
Occasionally, something goes wrong with a customer's order. To dispute a charge, a customer can create a dispute with PayPal. PayPal merchants, partners, and external developers can use the PayPal Disputes API to manage customer disputes.
Note: In the live environment, merchants cannot create disputes but can only respond to customer-created disputes. However, merchants can create disputes in the sandbox environment. When you create an app, enable Disputes in the App feature options section.
A customer can also ask his or her bank or credit card company to dispute and reverse a charge, which is known as a chargeback. For more information, see Disputes, claims, chargebacks, and bank reversals.

When a customer disputes a charge, you can use this API to provide evidence that the charge is legitimate. To provide evidence or appeal a dispute, you submit a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs.

Normally, an agent at PayPal creates a dispute, updates the dispute status, and settles disputes, but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that complete these operations.

Important: The create, cancel, compute metrics, change reason, and validate eligibility methods are available as a limited-release solution at this time. For more information, reach out to your PayPal account manager.

For details, see Disputes Overview documentation.

tags.name: disputes
tags.description: Use the `/disputes` resource to list disputes, create disputes, show dispute details, and partially a dispute. Normally, an agent at PayPal creates disputes but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that create disputes.

tags.name: disputes-actions
tags.description:
Use the `/disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to:
  • Accept a claim.
  • Accept an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Acknowledge the return of an item related to a dispute.
  • Settle a dispute.
  • Appeal a dispute.
  • Cancel a dispute.
  • Change the reason for a dispute.
  • Deny an offer to resolve dispute.
  • Escalate a dispute to a claim.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Provide evidence for a dispute.
  • Provide supporting information for dispute.
  • In the sandbox, update the dispute status.
  • Send a message about a dispute to the other party in the dispute.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/customer/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: validate-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-eligibility/` resource to determine whether you can create a case for a transaction.

tags.name: compute-metrics
tags.description: Use the `/compute-metrics` resource to provide metrics for all disputes.

tags.name: validate-referred-dispute-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-referred-dispute-eligibility` resource to determine whether you can create a referred case for a transaction, by encrypted transaction ID.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: referred-disputes-actions
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to notify PayPal about adjudication updates for a referred dispute and notify PayPal about a refund for a referred dispute.

tags.name: partner-actions
tags.description: Use the `/disputes/{id}/partner-actions/` resource to show dispute action details and partially update a dispute action.

tags.name: search-suggestions
tags.description: Use the `/search-suggestions` resource to show search suggestions.

tags.name: dispute-events
tags.description: Use the `/dispute-events` resource to send dispute events.

tags.name: refund-preference
tags.description: Use the `/disputes/{id}/provide-refund-preference` resource to provide refund preferences for the dispute.

tags.name: return-compensation
tags.description: Use the `/disputes/{id}/return-compensation` resource to return the compensation on the dispute provided by PayPal to the customer.

get.description:
Lists disputes with a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_state, dispute_life_cycle_stage, dispute_channel, dispute_amount, create_time and update_time fields.

To filter the disputes in the response, specify one or more optional query parameters. To limit the number of disputes in the response, specify the page_size query parameter.

To list multiple disputes, set these query parameters in the request:
  • page_size=2
  • start_time instead of disputed_transaction_id

If the response contains more than two disputes, it lists two disputes and includes a HATEOAS link to the next page of results.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP 200 OK status code and a JSON response body that lists disputes with a full or summary set of details. Default is a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_amount, create_time, and update_time fields for each dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

get.description:
Shows details for a dispute, by ID.
Note: The fields that appear in the response depend on the access. For example, if the merchant requests shows dispute details, the customer's email ID does not appear.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that shows dispute details.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

patch.description: Partially updates a dispute, by ID. Seller can update the `communication_detail` value or The partner can add the `partner action` information.

202.description: A successfully accepted request returns the HTTP `202 Accepted` status code and a JSON response body that includes a [HATEOAS link](/docs/api/reference/api-responses/#hateoas-links) to the ID of the request. The Clients can choose webhook option as well to receive dispute update notification.

204.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `204 No Content` status code with no JSON response body.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.description:
Provides evidence for a dispute, by ID. A merchant can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE status while customers can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE status. Evidence can be a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs. A proof of delivery document includes a tracking number while a proof of refund document includes a refund ID. For other evidence type, notes and documents can be given. Evidences requested from you can be found by checking the type of evidence for the corresponding source under the evidence section of the show dispute details response. The source will be REQUESTED_FROM_SELLER for evidences requested from the merchant while it will be REQUESTED_FROM_BUYER for evidences requested from the customer. For constraints and rules regarding documents, see documents.
To make this request, specify the evidence in the JSON request body and use the provide-evidence link in the HATEOAS links of the show dispute details response. In case the link is not present in the response, you can't provide evidence for the dispute. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

post.description:
Appeals a dispute, by ID. To appeal a dispute, use the appeal link in the HATEOAS links from the show dispute details response. If this link does not appear, you cannot appeal the dispute. Submit new evidence as a document or notes in the JSON request body. For constraints and rules regarding documents, see documents.
To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the evidence in the JSON request body. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

post.description: Accepts liability for a claim, by ID. When you accept liability for a claim, the dispute closes in the customer’s favor and PayPal automatically refunds money to the customer from the merchant's account. Allowed accept_claim_type values for the request is available in dispute details allowed response options object.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

post.description:
Important: This method is for sandbox use only.
Settles a dispute in either the customer's or merchant's favor. Merchants can make this call in the sandbox to complete end-to-end dispute resolution testing, which mimics the dispute resolution that PayPal agents normally complete. To make this call, the dispute status must be UNDER_REVIEW and adjudicate link should be available in the HATEOAS links of the show dispute details response.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.description:
Important: This method is for sandbox use only.
Updates the status of a dispute, by ID, from UNDER_REVIEW to either:
  • WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
  • WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE
This status change enables either the customer or merchant to submit evidence for the dispute. To make this call, the dispute status must be UNDER_REVIEW and require-evidence link should be available in the HATEOAS links of the show dispute details response. Specify an action value in the JSON request body to indicate whether the status change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence:
If action isThe status updates to
BUYER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
SELLER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE
.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

value.note: Escalating to PayPal claim for resolution.

post.description: Escalates the dispute, by ID, to a PayPal claim. To make this call, the stage in the dispute lifecycle must be `INQUIRY`.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.summary: Send message about dispute to other party
post.description: Sends a message about a dispute, by ID, to the other party in the dispute. Merchants and customers can only send messages if the `dispute_life_cycle_stage` value is `INQUIRY`. For constraints and rules regarding documents that can be attached as part of the message, see documents. To send a message, use the send-message link in the HATEOAS links of the show dispute details response and specify the message in the JSON request body. In case the link is not present in the response you can't send a message on the dispute.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

message_document.description: A file that contains any additional info about the message posted.

post.description: Makes an offer to the other party to resolve a dispute, by ID. To make this call, the stage in the dispute lifecycle must be `INQUIRY`. If the customer accepts the offer, PayPal automatically makes a refund. Allowed offer_type values for the request is available in dispute details allowed response options object.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.description: The customer accepts the offer from merchant to resolve a dispute, by ID. PayPal automatically refunds the amount proposed by merchant to the customer.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

202.description: A successfully accepted request returns the HTTP `202 Accepted` status code and a JSON response body that includes a [HATEOAS link](/docs/api/reference/api-responses/#hateoas-links) to the ID of the request. The request returns `202 Accepted` status in case money movement for the offer is delayed due to some internal reasons.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

value.note: I am ok with the refund offered.

post.description: Denies an offer that the merchant proposes for a dispute, by ID.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.description: Acknowledges that the customer returned an item for a dispute, by ID. A merchant can make this request for disputes with the `MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED` reason. Allowed acknowledgement_type values for the request is available in dispute details allowed response options object. For constraints and rules regarding documents, see documents.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

post.description:
Provides supporting information for a dispute, by ID. A merchant or buyer can make this request for disputes if they find the `provide-supporting-info` link in the HATEOAS links in the list disputes response. The party can provide the supporting information to PayPal to defend themselves only when the `dispute_life_cycle_stage` is `CHARGEBACK`, `PRE_ARBITRATION`, or `ARBITRATION`. They can provide a note that describes their part with details or upload any supporting documents to support their side. For constraints and rules regarding documents, see documents.
To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the notes in the JSON request body. This method differs from the provide evidence method which supports only multipart request, where PayPal asks the concerned party for evidence.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

404.description: The request failed due to the dispute is not available. The request returns the HTTP `404 Not Found` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

scopes.https://uri.paypal.com/services/disputes: This privilege allows client to read and search a disputes of a merchant but gets only a limited and allowed set of fields back .
This privilege allows client to read and search disputes but returns a limited and allowed set of fields back.
This privilege allows client to read and search a disputes of an user but gets only a limited and allowed set of fields back to ebay.
This privilege allows client to read and search a dispute of an user with all fields.
This privilege allows webhook platform to read a dispute event
This privilege allows client to validate eligibility and create a dispute on his transaction(s).
This privilege allows client to update a dispute (Merchant actions).
This privilege allows client to update a dispute (customer actions).
scopes.https://uri.paypal.com/services/referred: This privilege allows client to read and update a referred dispute.
scopes.https://uri.paypal.com/services/disputes: This privilege allows client to read and search disputes but returns a limited and allowed set of fields back.
This privilege allows client to update a dispute (Partner actions).

accept_claim_response_options.title: Accept Claim Response Options
accept_claim_response_options.description: The allowed response options when the merchant is accepting the claim.

accept_claim_type.title: Accept Claim Type
accept_claim_type.description: The refund type proposed by the merchant for the dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant must refund the customer without any item replacement or return. This type is applicable when a merchant is willing to refund the entire dispute amount without any further action from customer. Omit the refund_amount and return_shipping_address parameters from the accept claim call.

The customer must return the item to the merchant and then merchant will refund the money. This type is applicable when a merchant is willing to refund the dispute amount and requires the customer to return the item. Include the return_shipping_address parameter in but omit the refund_amount parameter from the accept claim call.
The merchant proposes a partial refund for the dispute.This type is applicable when a merchant is willing to refund an amount lesser than dispute amount. Include the refund_amount parameter.

The customer must return the item to the merchant and then merchant will refund the money. This type is applicable when a merchant is willing to refund the dispute amount and requires the customer to return the item using the shipment label provided by the merchant. Include the return_shipment_info and return_shipping_address parameter in but omit the refund_amount parameter from the accept claim call.

accept_claim_type_list.description: The types of refund the merchant can provide the customer.

accept_offer.title: Accept Offer Request
accept_offer.description: A customer request to accept the offer made by the merchant.

note.description: The customer notes about accepting of offer. PayPal can but the merchant cannot view these notes.

acknowledge_return_item_response_options.title: Acknowledge Return Item Response Options
acknowledge_return_item_response_options.description: The allowed response options when the seller acknowledges that the buyer has returned an item for the dispute.

acknowledgement_type.title: Allowed Acknowledgement Type
acknowledgement_type.description: The type of acknowledgement allowed for the merchant after the customer has returned the item. The merchant can update whether the item was received and is as expected or if the item was not received.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant has received the item returned by the customer.
The merchant has not received the item.
The items returned by the customer were damaged.
The package was empty or the goods were different from what was expected.
The package did not have all the items that were expected.

acknowledgement_type_list.description: The types of response when the merchant acknowledges a returned item.

action_info.title: Evidence Extensions
action_info.description: The extended properties for a evidence. Includes additional information such as the action for which the evidence was requested/submitted, and whether the evidence is mandatory.

action.description: The action for which the evidence was requested or submitted.

response_option.description:
The response option for the corresponding action. Possible values:
  • Acknowledgement Types
  • Accept Claim types
.

mandatory.description: Indicates whether the evidence is mandatory for the corresponding action and response option.

address_details.title: Address Details
address_details.description:
The non-portable additional address details that are sometimes needed for compliance, risk, or other scenarios where fine-grain address information might be needed. Not portable with common third party and open source. Redundant with core fields.
For example, `address_portable.address_line_1` is usually a combination of `address_details.street_number`, `street_name`, and `street_type`.

street_name.description: The street name. Just `Drury` in `Drury Lane`.

street_type.description: The street type. For example, avenue, boulevard, road, or expressway.

delivery_service.description: The delivery service. Post office box, bag number, or post office name.

building_name.description: A named locations that represents the premise. Usually a building name or number or collection of buildings with a common name or number. For example, Craven House.

sub_building.description: The first-order entity below a named building or location that represents the sub-premises. Usually a single building within a collection of buildings with a common name. Can be a flat, story, floor, room, or apartment.

address_portable.title: Portable Postal Address (Medium-Grained)
address_portable.description: The portable international postal address. Maps to [AddressValidationMetadata](https://github.com/googlei18n/libaddressinput/wiki/AddressValidationMetadata) and HTML 5.1 [Autofilling form controls: the autocomplete attribute](https://www.w3.org/TR/html51/sec-forms.html#autofilling-form-controls-the-autocomplete-attribute).

address_line_1.description: The first line of the address. For example, number or street. For example, `173 Drury Lane`. Required for data entry and compliance and risk checks. Must contain the full address.

address_line_2.description: The second line of the address. For example, suite or apartment number.

address_line_3.description: The third line of the address, if needed. For example, a street complement for Brazil, direction text, such as `next to Walmart`, or a landmark in an Indian address.

admin_area_4.description:
The neighborhood, ward, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_3` or `sub_locality`. Value is:
  • The postal sorting code for Guernsey and many French territories, such as French Guiana.
  • The fine-grained administrative levels in China.

admin_area_3.description:
A sub-locality, suburb, neighborhood, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_2`. Value is:
  • Brazil. Suburb, bairro, or neighborhood.
  • India. Sub-locality or district. Street name information is not always available but a sub-locality or district can be a very small area.

admin_area_2.description: A city, town, or village. Smaller than `admin_area_level_1`.

admin_area_1.description:
The highest level sub-division in a country, which is usually a province, state, or ISO-3166-2 subdivision. Format for postal delivery. For example, `CA` and not `California`. Value, by country, is:
  • UK. A county.
  • US. A state.
  • Canada. A province.
  • Japan. A prefecture.
  • Switzerland. A kanton.

postal_code.description: The postal code, which is the zip code or equivalent. Typically required for countries with a postal code or an equivalent. See [postal code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_code).

adjudicate.title: Settle Request
adjudicate.description: A request to settle a dispute in either the customer's or merchant's favor.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Resolves the case in the customer's favor. Outcome is set to RESOLVED_BUYER_FAVOR.
Resolves the case in the merchant's favor. Outcome is set to RESOLVED_SELLER_FAVOR.

adjudication.title: Adjudication
adjudication.description: The Adjudication details for the dispute.

adjudication_time.description: The date and time when the adjudication was done, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

reason.description: The reason for the adjudication type.

dispute_life_cycle_stage.description: The dispute life cycle stage during the adjudication.

adjudication_list.description: The Teammate Adjudication details for the dispute.

adjudication_reason.description: The reason for the adjudication type.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Seller submitted proof of correct charge.
Seller had disclosed billing agreement changes upfront.
Seller had not disclosed billing agreement changes upfront.
Seller had shared change in billing agreement date upfront.
Seller had not shared change in billing agreement date upfront.
Buyer has attempted to return the item.
Buyer was charged only once and did not submit sufficient evidence of duplicate charge.
Buyer cancelled the service or recurring transaction.
Buyer did not describe the issue to justify the refund.
Buyer continues to possess the item or has received the service.
Buyer did not attempt to resolve the issue with the seller.
Buyer is not in possession of the item to be returned.
Buyer provided credit receipt or relevant documentation.
Billing agreement was cancelled as per agreed terms.
Buyer in possession of the card which was reported as stolen or lost.
Buyer reported card as lost or stolen after the authorization date.
Buyer recognizes the transaction as valid.
Case decision was made as per available information when specific reasons are not applicable.
Item or service was delivered after the expected delivery date had passed.
Delivery of the item or service is due within the expected delivery date.
Seller refused delivery or service of the item.
Documentation provided supports the amount that was charged.
Documentation provided supports the amount charged on buyer's account.

The case is decided based on Protection Policy.

The pattern identified does not meet buyer protection eligibility.
The pattern identified does not meet seller protection eligibility.
Seller agreed to replace the item.
Seller agreed to issue a partial refund to the buyer.
Seller agreed to issue a refund for item return.

Seller appealed twice for the same reason with invalid reason.
The case is decided as invalid based on external network policy.
Seller provided invalid proof of delivery.
Buyer's signature confirmation missing in proof of delivery.
The documentation provided is not valid.
Seller provided invalid proof of shipment.
Seller provided invalid proof of refund.
Seller's signature confirmation missing in proof of return.
Buyer provided invalid proof of return.
Item was altered or repaired while in buyer's possession.
Item or service provided didn’t match as it was advertised.
Item or service provided didn’t match as it was described.
Item or service provided was not damaged or missing any parts.
Seller did not deliver the item to the buyer.
Item was not returned to seller.
Seller did not provide verified proof of shipment or delivery.
Item sent to the buyer was of different quality, quantity, color, or size.
Item was not delivered as it was no longer in stock.
Buyer returned the item to seller.
Seller's listing accurately represented the item.
Buyer received the item or service from the seller.
Item was sold in the condition as described by the seller.
Item value or usability was not affected significantly.
Seller appealed multiple times for the same reason with no additional compelling evidence.
No documentation given to support that credit is due to buyer.
Seller did not provide proof of delivery.
Seller did not provide proof of fulfillment for a service or digital good.
Digital goods, services, or other Intangibles not covered under Protection Policies.
No response from buyer to the request for additional information.
No response from seller to the request for additional information.
Seller did not provide valid proof of shipment.
No evidence of a billing error.
No evidence of unauthorized account access was found.
Funds only added once and no duplication.
Funds only withdrawn once and no duplication.
Seller did not ship to correct address.
Seller issued refund for missing items.
Buyer accepted the partial refund offer.
Payment was previously refunded or reversed.
Seller submitted proof of shipment instead of proof of delivery.
Pre-authorized installment or balance is due to seller.
Buyer submitted proof of being billed after the billing agreement was cancelled.
Buyer submitted proof that this was paid by another payment method.
Bank or Credit does not match withdrawal amount on PayPal.
Buyer did not provide sufficient proof of paying by other means.
Buyer did not provide sufficient proof of tracking for returns.
This case is covered under Seller protection program.
Paypal covered the cost of the case as decided by policy.
Seller received multiple payments for the same purchase.
Seller chose to issue a refund without requiring item to be returned.
Seller agreed to refund the buyer.
Seller has earlier issued a credit to the buyer for the same transaction.
Seller could not be reached to resolve case.
Seller received the payment twice or received payment for a replacement item.
Seller declined to issue a refund.
Seller declined to accept return of the item.
Surcharge was assessed to the buyer.
Service was not completed by seller as per description in the agreement.
Shipping company refused to ship the item.
For an item which was significantly not as described, seller cannot appeal with tracking information.
Card holder authorized the use of card for the transaction.
Transaction was cancelled after the authorization date.
Transaction was cancelled before the shipment or service date.
Transaction similar to recent spending patterns of buyer.
Payout to the buyer decided based on their profile and policy.
