Seller provided valid proof of refund.
Buyer provided valid documents to support claim.
Buyer provided valid proof of return delivery.
Buyer provided valid proof of return delivery with signature confirmation.
Seller provided valid proof of shipment.
The value of item or usability was affected significantly.
The case is decided based on Protection Policy.
The reason as to why the buyer is filing dispute after given specified days.
Funds were not transferred to the correct recipient.
The decision is to deny the buyer for the dispute.
The decision is to payout to the buyer.
The decision is to payout to the seller if the seller was debited earlier.
The decision is to charge the seller for the dispute if the seller was not debited already.

agreed_refund_details.title: Agreed Refund Details
agreed_refund_details.description: Details of Agreed Refund between customer and merchant.

merchant_agreed_refund.description: Indicates whether merchant has agreed to refund the buyer or not.

merchant_agreed_refund_time.description: The date and time proposed by merchant to provide the refund, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

allowed_response_options.title: Allowed Response Options
allowed_response_options.description: The allowed response options for the buyer/seller update actions.

buyer.title: Customer
buyer.description: The details for the customer who funds the payment. For example, the customer's first name, last name, and email address.

cancellation_date.description: The date and time of the cancellation, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

cancelled.description: Indicates whether the dispute was canceled.

cancellation_mode.description: Indicates the mode used for order cancellation.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The item was cancelled on the merchant's website.
The item was cancelled through either phone or fax.
The item was cancelled through either email or text message.
The item was cancelled via written communication.
The item was cancelled in person.

communication_details.title: Contact Details
communication_details.description: The contact details that a merchant provides to the customer to use to share their evidence documents.

email.description: The email address that is provided by the merchant where the customer can share the evidences.

note.description: The merchant provided notes that are visible to both the customer and PayPal.

time_posted.description: The date and time when the contact details were posted, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

country_code.description:
The [two-character ISO 3166-1 code](/api/rest/reference/country-codes/) that identifies the country or region.
Note: The country code for Great Britain is GB and not UK as used in the top-level domain names for that country. Use the `C2` country code for China worldwide for comparable uncontrolled price (CUP) method, bank card, and cross-border transactions.

cryptocurrency.title: Cryptocurrency
cryptocurrency.description: The details needed to represent a specific cryptocurrency balance, such as its symbol and quantity.

cryptocurrency_decimals.description: The number of decimal digits supported by this cryptocurrency. For example, for Bitcoin this value is 8 because there are 10^8 satoshis in one Bitcoin and for Ethereum it's 18 since there are 10^18 wei in one Ether.
cryptocurrency_decimals.title: Decimals

cryptocurrency_quantity.description: The quantity of a cryptocurrency asset. This is a decimal number with a scale defined for each cryptocurrency by its founders. For example, Bitcoin (BTC) has 8 as its scale, Ethereum (ETH) has 18 as its scale. The PayPal Cryptocurrency platform handles the scale to 8 digits for Bitcoin. including its forks or offshoots, as well as Ethereum.

cryptocurrency_subunits_quantity.title: Cryptocurrency Quantity Subunits
cryptocurrency_subunits_quantity.description:
The quantity of a cryptocurrency asset in the currency's sub units.
Amount is an integer in a string format.
Floating point should be avoided to avoid precision errors. For example:
  • Bitcoin(BTC) has 8 decimals,
    • so 1 BTC will be represented as 100000000 (1 followed by 8 zeroes).
  • Ethereum(ETH) has 18 decimals,
    • so 1 ETH will be represented as 1000000000000000000 (1 followed by 18 zeroes).

cryptocurrency_symbol.description: The cryptocurrency symbol or code ticker options. Assigned by liquidity providers and exchanges.

currency_code.description: The [three-character ISO-4217 currency code](/api/rest/reference/currency-codes/) that identifies the currency.

date_time.description:
The date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). Seconds are required while fractional seconds are optional.
Note: The regular expression provides guidance but does not reject all invalid dates.

definitions-sub_reasons.description: The sub-reason for the service issue.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The service was different from what was expected.

definitions-sub_reasons_list.description: An array of sub-reasons for the service issue.

deny_offer.title: Deny Offer Request
deny_offer.description: A customer request to deny the offer made by the merchant.

note.description: The customer notes about the denial of offer. PayPal can but the merchant cannot view these notes.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

dispute_asset.description: The asset in the transaction that the customer disputed.

fee_policy.description: Policy that determines whether the fee needs to be charged, retained or returned while moving the money as part of dispute process.

external_reason_code.description: The code that identifies the reason for the credit card chargeback. Each card issuer follows their own standards for defining reason type, code, and its format. For more details about the external reason code, see the card issue site. Available for only unbranded transactions.

buyer_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the customer must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the customer does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the merchant's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

seller_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the merchant must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the merchant does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the customer's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

dispute_channel.description: The channel where the customer created the dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The customer contacts PayPal to file a dispute with the merchant.
The customer contacts their card issuer or bank to request a refund.
Pre-chargeback alert when customer contacts their card issuer to request a refund.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

dispute_asset.description: The asset in the transaction that the customer disputed.

buyer_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the customer must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the customer does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the merchant's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

seller_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the merchant must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the merchant does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the customer's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

dispute_info_list.description: An array of disputes that match the filter criteria. Sorted in latest to earliest creation time order.

dispute_lifecycle_stage.description: The stage in the dispute lifecycle.

x-enumDescriptions.description:
A customer and merchant interact in an attempt to resolve a dispute without escalation to PayPal. Occurs when the customer:
  • Has not received goods or a service.
  • Reports that the received goods or service are not as described.
  • Needs more details, such as a copy of the transaction or a receipt.

A customer or merchant escalates an inquiry to a claim, which authorizes PayPal to investigate the case and make a determination. Occurs only when the dispute channel is INTERNAL. This stage is a PayPal dispute lifecycle stage and not a credit card or debit card chargeback. All notes that the customer sends in this stage are visible to PayPal agents only. The customer must wait for PayPal’s response before the customer can take further action. In this stage, PayPal shares dispute details with the merchant, who can complete one of these actions:
  • Accept the claim.
  • Submit evidence to challenge the claim.
  • Make an offer to the customer to resolve the claim.

The first appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a chargeback if PayPal's decision is not in the merchant's favor. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, PayPal considers the case resolved.

The second appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a dispute for a second time if the first appeal was denied. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, the case returns to a resolved status in pre-arbitration stage.

outcome_code.description: The outcome of a resolved dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The dispute was resolved in the customer's favor.
The dispute was resolved in the merchant's favor.
PayPal provided the merchant or customer with protection and the case is resolved.
A dispute was created for the same transaction ID, and the previous dispute was closed without any decision.

outcome_reason.description: The justification for the adjudication outcome.

amount_refunded.description: The amount that either the merchant or PayPal refunds the customer.

asset_refunded.description: The asset that either the merchant or PayPal refunds the customer.

dispute_reason.title: Dispute Reason
dispute_reason.description: The reason for the item-level dispute. For information about the required information for each dispute reason and associated evidence type, see dispute reasons.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The customer did not receive the merchandise or service.
The customer reports that the merchandise or service is not as described.
The customer did not authorize purchase of the merchandise or service.
The refund or credit was not processed for the customer.
The customer was charged an incorrect amount.
The customer paid for the transaction through other means.
The customer was being charged for a subscription or a recurring transaction that was canceled.
A problem occurred with the remittance.

dispute_search.title: Dispute Search Response
dispute_search.description: An array of disputes. Includes links that enable you to navigate through the response.

dispute_source.description: The dispute source through which customer initiated the dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The dispute is initiated through a email communication.
The dispute is filed directly on paypal website.
The dispute is initiated through a chat communication.
The dispute is initiated through automated phone system.
The dispute is initiated through a phone call from user.
The dispute is filed directly on paypal application on mobile.
The dispute is filed directly on paypal mobile web page.
The dispute is filed directly through API request.

dispute_state.title: Dispute State
dispute_state.description: The user specific state of the dispute, could vary between parties during the dispute lifecycle.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The dispute is waiting for a response.
The dispute is waiting for a response from other party.
The dispute is under review with PayPal.

document.title: Document
document.description: An uploaded document as a binary object that supports a dispute.

url.description:
The downloadable URL for the document for which the client has access.

Note: Document download may require some configuration setup and available as a limited release at this time. For more information, reach out to your PayPal account manager.
.

document_list.description: An array of metadata for the documents which contains any additional info about the message posted.

received_duplicate.description: If `true`, indicates that a duplicate transaction was received.

original_transaction.description: The transaction details for the original transaction, when the dispute reason is `DUPLICATE_TRANSACTION`. Currently, contains only the date and amount.

email_address.description:
The internationalized email address.
Note: Up to 64 characters are allowed before and 255 characters are allowed after the @ sign. However, the generally accepted maximum length for an email address is 254 characters. The pattern verifies that an unquoted @ sign exists.

name.description: The human-readable, unique name of the error.

message.description: The message that describes the error.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

information_link.description: The information link, or URI, that shows detailed information about this error for the developer.

error_400.title: Bad Request Error
error_400.description: Request is not well-formed, syntactically incorrect, or violates schema.

enum: Request is not well-formed, syntactically incorrect, or violates schema.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_401.title: Unauthorized Error
error_401.description: Authentication failed due to missing Authorization header, or invalid authentication credentials.

enum: Authentication failed due to missing authorization header, or invalid authentication credentials.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_403.title: Not Authorized Error
error_403.description: The client is not authorized to access this resource, although it may have valid credentials.

enum: Authorization failed due to insufficient permissions.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_404.title: Not found Error
error_404.description: The server has not found anything matching the request URI. This either means that the URI is incorrect or the resource is not available.

enum: The specified resource does not exist.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_409.title: Resource Conflict Error
error_409.description: The server has detected a conflict while processing this request.

enum: The server has detected a conflict while processing this request.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_415.title: Unsupported Media Type Error
error_415.description: The server does not support the request payload's media type.

enum: The server does not support the request payload's media type.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_422.title: Unprocessable Entity Error
error_422.description: The requested action cannot be performed and may require interaction with APIs or processes outside of the current request. This is distinct from a 500 response in that there are no systemic problems limiting the API from performing the request.

enum: The requested action could not be performed, semantically incorrect, or failed business validation.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_500.title: Internal Server Error
error_500.description: This is either a system or application error, and generally indicates that although the client appeared to provide a correct request, something unexpected has gone wrong on the server.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_503.title: Service Unavailable Error
error_503.description: The server is temporarily unable to handle the request, for example, because of planned maintenance or downtime.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID. Used for correlation purposes.

error_details.title: Error Details
error_details.description: The error details. Required for client-side `4XX` errors.

field.description: The field that caused the error. If this field is in the body, set this value to the field's JSON pointer value. Required for client-side errors.

value.description: The value of the field that caused the error.

issue.description: The unique, fine-grained application-level error code.

description.description: The human-readable description for an issue. The description can change over the lifetime of an API, so clients must not depend on this value.

error_details-2.title: Error Details
error_details-2.description: The error details. Required for client-side `4XX` errors.

field.description: The field that caused the error. If this field is in the body, set this value to the field's JSON pointer value. Required for client-side errors.

value.description: The value of the field that caused the error.

location.description: The location of the field that caused the error. Value is `body`, `path`, or `query`.

issue.description: The unique, fine-grained application-level error code.

description.description: The human-readable description for an issue. The description can change over the lifetime of an API, so clients must not depend on this value.

error_details_list.description: An array of additional details about the error.

href.description: The complete target URL. To make the related call, combine the method with this [URI Template-formatted](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570) link. For pre-processing, include the `$`, `(`, and `)` characters. The `href` is the key HATEOAS component that links a completed call with a subsequent call.

rel.description: The [link relation type](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4), which serves as an ID for a link that unambiguously describes the semantics of the link. See [Link Relations](https://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml).

method.description: The HTTP method required to make the related call.

error_location.description: The location of the field that caused the error. Value is `body`, `path`, or `query`.

escalate.title: Escalate Claim Request
escalate.description: A merchant request to escalate a dispute, by ID, to a PayPal claim.

note.description: The notes about the escalation of the dispute to a claim.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: A merchant- or customer-submitted evidence document. evidence_info is expected for PROOF_OF_FULFILLMENT,PROOF_OF_REFUND and PROOF_OF_RETURN evidence types. documents and notes can be given for rest of the evidence types.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Proof of fulfillment should be a copy of the actual shipping label on the package that shows the destination address and the shipping company's stamp to verify the shipment date.
Proof of refund issued to the buyer
Copy of original receipt or invoice.
Copy of terms and conditions,contract or store return policy
Proof of reshipment should be a copy of the actual shipping label on the package that shows the destination address and the shipping company's stamp to verify the reshipment date.
A copy of the original description of the item or service
Copy of the police report filed.
More information has to be provided about the claim using the affidavit.
Document showing item/service was paid by another payment method.
Explanation of what the price difference is related to (increased tip amount, shipping charges, taxes, etc).
Source of expected conversion rate or fee.
Proof of shipment or postage that shows you returned this item to your seller and should be a copy of the actual shipping label used.
Additional evidence information during case creation.
The evidence related to the reason change.
Document should show that the seller issued a refund outside Paypal.
Check with buyer if item Delivered (seller provided Proof of Shipping)
Document confirming that the item has been confiscated.
Custom fees receipt paid by the buyer
Any resolution reached with the seller should be communicated to PayPal.
Any additional information of the item purchased.
Specific details of a purchase made under a particular transaction has to be given.
More information required on how the item was damaged or was significantly different from the item advertised.
Any screenshot or download/usage log showing that the software or service was unavailable or non-functional.
Documentation from a third party or organization that evaluated this item that confirms they confiscated it.
Documentation supporting the claim that the item is damaged.

Report filed with a law enforcement agency or government organization. Examples of such agencies are -  Internet Crime Complaint Center (www.ic3.gov), state Consumer Protection office, state police or a Federal law enforcement agency such as the FBI or Postal Inspection Service.
Additional proof of shipment  such as a packing list, detailed invoice, or shipping manifest to confirm that all items have been shipped. Include carrier name and tracking number if available.
Documentation from the carrier should confirm the reason why they refuse to ship the item in question and the extent of the original damage.

Proof should be provided by an unbiased third-party, such as a dealer, appraiser or another individual or organisation that's qualified in the area of the item in question (other than yourself), and detail the extent of the damage or clearly explain how the item received significantly differs from the item advertised.

The document you have provided doesn't support your claim that the item is Significantly Not as Described. Please provide a document to clearly show how the item received significantly differs from the item advertised.
The document you have provided is illegible, unclear, or too dark to read.  Please provide a document that is legible and clear to read.
Online tracking information for remaining items that have to be shipped to the seller.
Confirmation that the item has been received.
In-store receipt or online verification should clearly show that the buyer picked up the item.
Tracking information should include the carrier name,  online tracking number and the website where the shipment can be tracked.
Proof of shipment or postage should be a copy of the actual shipping label on the package that shows the destination address and the carrier's stamp to verify the shipment date.
Online tracking information to confirm delivery of item.
Proof should be an in-store refund receipt or company documentation that clearly shows a completed refund for the transaction.

Proof should be compelling evidence to prove that the item or service was as described  and was delivered to the buyer. Include information such as transaction ID, invoice ID, name or email to associate the evidence with the buyer along with date and time of the delivery.
Return address is required for the buyer to ship  the merchandise back to the seller.
To validate a claim,  a copy of the eparcel manifest showing the buyer's address from Australia Post is required.
The shipping manifest must show the buyer's address and can be obtained from the carrier.
Appeal affidavit is needed to make an appeal for any case outcome.
Check with buyer if the replacement of the item sent by the seller was received
Additional Details about how account was accessed/what was changed.
Address where item was supposed to be delivered.
Confirmation that item was received and issue resolved.
Copy of merchant's response when the resolution was attempted.
A Detailed description about the account or card level permission given to another person.
Details of the merchandise's current location.
Details of where and when the card was lost/stolen?.
Details of the last valid transaction made on the card.
Document to confirm that the item to be returned to the seller has been shipped.
Signed declaration about the information provided.
Image of open box with returned items and shipping label clearly visible.
Image of empty box or returned items that are different from what were expected and shipping label clearly visible.
Any proof about the non receipt of the item, such as screenshot of tracking info.
Order details or photos of the item/service/booking/digital download available on the website.
The website URLs of the item/service/booking/digital download.
Insurance information of the shipped item.
Copy of the buyer response or any other document showing buyer's understanding of the item/service/booking/digital download purchased.
Photos of the item that were shipped to the buyer.
Cancellation details information, for example- cancellation date, cancellation number.
Merchant contacted details information, for example- merchant contacted time, mode of contacting.
Item related details information, for example- expected delivery date.
Proof of the correct recipient name, email or phone.
Details on why the funds were not delivered to the correct recipient.
PayPal requested evidence from the customer.
PayPal requested evidence from the merchant.
Evidence was submitted by the customer.
Evidence was submitted by the merchant.
Evidence was submitted by the partner.

date.description: The date and time when the evidence was received, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

item_id.description: The item ID. If the merchant provides multiple pieces of evidence and the transaction has multiple item IDs, the merchant can use this value to associate a piece of evidence with an item ID.

item_type.description: The item type for which the evidence is requested or submitted.

action_info.description: The action details for the information. Includes additional information such as the action for which the evidence was requested/submitted, and whether the evidence is mandatory for the corresponding action.

dispute_life_cycle_stage.description: The dispute life cycle stage for the evidence.

extensions.title: Extensions
extensions.description: The extended properties for the dispute. Includes additional information for a dispute category, such as billing disputes, the original transaction ID, and the correct amount.

merchant_contacted.description: Indicates that the merchant was contacted.

merchant_contacted_time.description: The date and time when merchant was contacted.

merchant_contacted_mode.description: The method used to contact the merchant.

buyer_contacted_time.description: The date and time when the buyer contacted the partner to file a dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

buyer_contacted_channel.description: The channel through which the buyer contacted the partner to file a dispute. Partners that allow buyers to create dispute from multiple channels can use this field to help identify which channel was used for each individual dispute.

fee_policy.title: Fee Policy
fee_policy.description: Policy that determines whether the fee needs to be charged, retained or returned while moving the money as part of dispute process.

fund_movement.title: Fund movement
fund_movement.description: This section contains the details about the fund movement of the parties ,time , direction and the reason for it.

party.description: The affected party in the money movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The money movement is related to the seller.
The money movement is related to the buyer.
The money movement is related to the payment processing tenants such as PayPal, Venmo, Braintree etc.

amount.description: The amount transferred as part of the money movement.

asset.description: The asset transferred as part of the money movement.

initiated_time.description: The date and time when the money movement was initiated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

type.description: The type of the money movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The money movement is a debit transaction.
The money movement is a credit transaction.

reason.description: The reason for the fund movement.

fund_movement_list.description: The movements of fund due to the dispute.

fund_movement_reason.description: The reason for the fund movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The fee amount reimbursed to the seller as part of the dispute resolution process.
The money movement is for dispute settlement.

The money movement is for dispute fee which PayPal charges to sellers for facilitating the online dispute resolution process for transactions that are processed either through a buyer’s PayPal account or through a PayPal guest checkout.

The money movement is for chargeback fee which PayPal charges to sellers for facilitating the chargeback process for transactions that are not processed either through a buyer’s PayPal account or through a guest checkout, and where the buyer pursues a chargeback for the transaction with their card issuer.

correct_transaction_asset.description: The correct asset quantity of the transaction.

correct_transaction_time.description: The date and time when the customer created the transaction, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

item_info.title: Item Information
item_info.description: The information for a purchased item in a disputed transaction.

item_id.description: The item ID. If the merchant provides multiple pieces of evidence and the transaction has multiple item IDs, the merchant can use this value to associate a piece of evidence with an item ID.

item_quantity.description: The count of the item in the dispute. Must be a whole number.

partner_transaction_id.description: The ID of the transaction in the partner system. The partner transaction ID is returned at an item level because the partner might show different transactions for different items in the cart.

dispute_amount.description: The amount of the item in the dispute.

notes.description: Any notes provided with the item.

item_info_list.description: An array of items that were purchased as part of the transaction.

item_type.title: Item Type
item_type.description: The type of the item which has the issue.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The digital download has an issue.

href.description: The complete target URL. To make the related call, combine the method with this [URI Template-formatted](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570) link. For pre-processing, include the `$`, `(`, and `)` characters. The `href` is the key HATEOAS component that links a completed call with a subsequent call.

rel.description: The [link relation type](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4), which serves as an ID for a link that unambiguously describes the semantics of the link. See [Link Relations](https://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml).

method.description: The HTTP method required to make the related call.

make_offer.title: Make Offer Request
make_offer.description: A merchant request to make an offer to resolve a dispute.

note.description: The merchant's notes about the offer.

offer_amount.description: The amount proposed to resolve the dispute.

return_shipping_address.description: The return address for the item. Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason, especially if the refund amount is less than the dispute amount.

invoice_id.description: The merchant-provided ID of the invoice for the refund. This optional value maps the refund to an invoice ID in the merchant's system.

make_offer_response_options.title: Make Offer Response Options
make_offer_response_options.description: The allowed response options when the merchant makes offer to the customer.

merchandize_dispute_properties.title: Merchandise Dispute Properties
merchandize_dispute_properties.description: The customer-provided merchandise issue details for the dispute.

return_shipping_address.description: The return address for the item. Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason.

merchant_contacted_mode.title: Merchant Contacted Method
merchant_contacted_mode.description: The method used to contact the merchant.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant was contacted through his website.
The merchant was contacted through either phone or fax.
The merchant was contacted through either email or text message.
The merchant was contacted through a written communication.
The merchant was contacted in person.

merchant_contacted_outcome.title: Merchant Contacted Outcome
merchant_contacted_outcome.description: The outcome when the customer has contacted the merchant.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant did not respond to the customer.
The merchant agreed to fix the issue but did not fix it yet.
The merchant could not fix the issue.

message.title: Message
message.description: A customer- or merchant-posted message for the dispute.

posted_by.description: Indicates whether the customer, merchant, or dispute arbiter posted the message.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The arbiter of the dispute posted the message.

time_posted.description: The date and time when the message was posted, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

message_list.description: An array of customer- or merchant-posted messages for the dispute.

money.title: Money
money.description: The currency and amount for a financial transaction, such as a balance or payment due.

value.description:
The value, which might be:
  • An integer for currencies like `JPY` that are not typically fractional.
  • A decimal fraction for currencies like `TND` that are subdivided into thousandths.
For the required number of decimal places for a currency code, see [Currency Codes](/api/rest/reference/currency-codes/).

money_movement.title: Money movement
money_movement.description: The Money movement details with party.

affected_party.description: The affected party in the money movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The money movement is related to the seller.
The money movement is related to the buyer.
The money movement is related to the payment processing tenants such as PayPal, Venmo, Braintree etc.

amount.description: The amount transferred as part of the money movement.

asset.description: The asset transferred as part of the money movement.

initiated_time.description: The date and time when the money movement was initiated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

type.description: The type of the money movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The money movement is a debit transaction.
The money movement is a credit transaction.

reason.description: The reason for the money movement.

money_movement_list.description: DEPRECATED The Money movement details for the dispute.

money_movement_reason.description: The reason for the money movement.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The fee is for dispute settlement.
The money movement is for dispute settlement.

The money movement is for dispute fee which PayPal charges to sellers for facilitating the online dispute resolution process for transactions that are processed either through a buyer’s PayPal account or through a PayPal guest checkout.

The money movement is for chargeback fee which PayPal charges to sellers for facilitating the chargeback process for transactions that are not processed either through a buyer’s PayPal account or through a guest checkout, and where the buyer pursues a chargeback for the transaction with their card issuer.

offer.title: Offer
offer.description: The merchant-proposed offer for a dispute.

buyer_requested_amount.description: The customer-requested refund for this dispute.

seller_offered_amount.description: The merchant-offered refund for this dispute.

offer_time.description: The date and time when the event occurred, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

event_type.description: The type of the history event.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant or customer proposed an offer.
The merchant or customer accepted the offer.
The merchant or customer rejected the offer.

dispute_life_cycle_stage.description: The dispute life cycle stage during the offer event.

offer_history_list.description: An array of history information for an offer.

offer_type.title: Offer Type
offer_type.description: The merchant-proposed offer type for the dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The merchant must refund the customer without any item replacement or return. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase and occurs when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount. Buyer acceptance is needed for partial refund offers and dispute is auto closed for full refunds. Include the offer_amount but omit the return_shipping_address parameters from the make offer request.

The customer must return the item to the merchant and then merchant will refund the money. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase and occurs when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount and requires the customer to return the item. Include the return_shipping_address parameter and the offer_amount parameter in the make offer request.

The merchant must do a refund and then send a replacement item to the customer. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount and send the replacement item. Include the offer_amount parameter in the make offer request.

The merchant must send a replacement item to the customer with no additional refunds. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to replace the item without any refund. Omit the offer_amount parameter from the make offer request.

offer_type_list.description: The types of offer the merchant can offer the customer.

patch.title: Patch
patch.description: The JSON patch object to apply partial updates to resources.

x-enumDescriptions.description:
Depending on the target location reference, completes one of these functions:
  • The target location is an array index. Inserts a new value into the array at the specified index.
  • The target location is an object parameter that does not already exist. Adds a new parameter to the object.
  • The target location is an object parameter that does exist. Replaces that parameter's value.
The value parameter defines the value to add. For more information, see 4.1. add.
Removes the value at the target location. For the operation to succeed, the target location must exist. For more information, see 4.2. remove.

Replaces the value at the target location with a new value. The operation object must contain a value parameter that defines the replacement value. For the operation to succeed, the target location must exist. For more information, see 4.3. replace.

Removes the value at a specified location and adds it to the target location. The operation object must contain a from parameter, which is a string that contains a JSON pointer value that references the location in the target document from which to move the value. For the operation to succeed, the from location must exist. For more information, see 4.4. move.

Copies the value at a specified location to the target location. The operation object must contain a from parameter, which is a string that contains a JSON pointer value that references the location in the target document from which to copy the value. For the operation to succeed, the from location must exist. For more information, see 4.5. copy.

Tests that a value at the target location is equal to a specified value. The operation object must contain a value parameter that defines the value to compare to the target location's value. For the operation to succeed, the target location must be equal to the value value. For test, equal indicates that the value at the target location and the value that value defines are of the same JSON type. The data type of the value determines how equality is defined:
TypeConsidered equal if both values
stringsContain the same number of Unicode characters and their code points are byte-by-byte equal.
numbersAre numerically equal.
arraysContain the same number of values, and each value is equal to the value at the corresponding position in the other array, by using these type-specific rules.
objectsContain the same number of parameters, and each parameter is equal to a parameter in the other object, by comparing their keys (as strings) and their values (by using these type-specific rules).
literals (false, true, and null)Are the same. The comparison is a logical comparison. For example, whitespace between the parameter values of an array is not significant. Also, ordering of the serialization of object parameters is not significant.
For more information, see 4.6. test.

path.description: The JSON Pointer to the target document location at which to complete the operation.

value.title: Patch Value
value.description: The value to apply. The remove, copy, and move operations do not require a value. Since JSON Patch allows any type for value, the type property is not specified.

from.description: The JSON Pointer to the target document location from which to move the value. Required for the move operation.

patch_request.title: Patch Request
patch_request.description: An array of JSON patch objects to apply partial updates to resources.

payment_by_other_means.title: Payment by Other Means
payment_by_other_means.description: The payment by other means details.

charge_different_from_original.description: If `true`, indicates that a charge was made that is different from the original charge.

received_duplicate.description: If `true`, indicates that a duplicate transaction was received.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The payment method was a credit card.
The payment method was a check.
The payment method was a debit card.
The payment method was a gift card.
The payment method was through bank transfer.

payment_instrument_suffix.description: Last 2-4 characters of the payment instrument. For payment_method CHECK, payment_instrument_suffix entered must be of minimum length 2-4 characters. For payment_method CREDIT_CARD, DEBIT_CARD, GIFT_CARD, BANK_TRANSFER, payment_instrument_suffix entered must be of length 4.

product_received.description: Indicates whether the product was, or was not, received or returned.

product_received_time.description: The date and time when product was delivered.

expected_delivery_date.description: The expected delivery date and time of the product.

purchase_url.description: The URL where the customer purchased the product.

refund_ids.description: The ID of the refunded transaction.

refund_ids_list.description: An array of refund IDs for the transaction involved in this dispute.

require_evidence.title: Require Evidence Request
require_evidence.description: Sandbox only. Updates the state of a dispute, by ID, to either WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE or WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE. This state change enables either the customer or merchant to submit evidence for the dispute. Specify an action value in the JSON request body to indicate whether the state change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence.

action.description: The action. Indicates whether the state change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Changes the status of the dispute to WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE.
Changes the status of the dispute to WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE.

return_details.title: Return Details
return_details.description: The return details for the product.

return_time.description: The date and time when the product was returned, [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

mode.description: The method that the customer used to return the product.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The customer shipped the product back to the merchant.
The customer returned the item to the merchant in person.

receipt.description: Indicates whether customer has the return receipt.

return_confirmation_number.description: The confirmation number for the item return.

returned.description: If `true`, indicates that the item was returned but the seller refused to accept the return and if `false`, indicates the item was not attempted to return.

seller.title: Merchant
seller.description: The details for the merchant who receives the funds and fulfills the order. For example, merchant ID, and contact email address.

email.description: The email address for the merchant's PayPal account.

merchant_id.description: The PayPal account ID for the merchant.

service_started.description: Indicates whether the service was started or cancelled.

note.description: The customer specified note about the service usage.

purchase_url.description: The URL of the merchant or marketplace site where the customer purchased the service.

status.description: The overall status of the dispute, constant for all the parties involved at anytime during the dispute lifecycle.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The dispute is waiting for a response from the customer.
The dispute is waiting for a response from the merchant.
The dispute is under review with PayPal.
The default status if the dispute does not have one of the other statuses.

sub_reasons.description: The sub-reason for the product issue.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The product was different from what was expected.

sub_reasons_list.description: An array of sub-reasons for the product issue.

supporting_info.title: Supporting Info
supporting_info.description: A merchant- or customer-submitted supporting information.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Information was submitted by the customer.
Information was submitted by the merchant.
Information was submitted by the partner.

provided_time.description: The date and time when the information was received, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

dispute_life_cycle_stage.description: The dispute life cycle stage for the supporting info.

supporting_info_definitions-document_lis.description: An array of metadata for the documents which were uploaded as supporting information for the dispute.

supporting_info_list.description: An array of all the supporting information that are associated to this dispute.

carrier_name.description: The name of the shipment carrier for the transaction for this dispute.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Post SDS EMS Express Mail Service Ireland.
China Post EMS Express Mail Service.
GLS General Logistics Systems Slovakia s.r.o.
Shree Maruti Courier Services Pvt Ltd
STEP FORWARD FREIGHT SERVICE CO LTD
SHREE TIRUPATI COURIER SERVICES PVT. LTD.
Skynet World Wide Express South Africa
Hermes Einrichtungs Service GmbH & Co. KG
Line Clear Express & Logistics Sdn Bhd

carrier_name_other.description: The name of carrier in free-form text for unavailable carriers. This field is mandatory when carrier_name is OTHER.

tracking_url.description: The URL to track the dispute-related transaction shipment.

tracking_number.description: The number to track the dispute-related transaction shipment.

tracking_info_list.description: An array of relevant tracking information for the transaction involved in this dispute.

transaction_info.title: Transaction Information
transaction_info.description: The information about the disputed transaction.

buyer_transaction_id.description: The ID, as seen by the customer, for this transaction.

seller_transaction_id.description: The ID, as seen by the merchant, for this transaction.

reference_id.description: The ID, as seen by the partner, for this transaction.

create_time.description: The date and time when the transaction was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

x-enumDescriptions.description: The items in the transaction are unclaimed. If they are not claimed within 30 days, the funds are returned to the sender.
The transaction is waiting to be processed.
The payment for the transaction was partially refunded.
The payment for the transaction was successfully refunded.
The payment for the transaction was reversed due to a chargeback or other reversal type.

gross_amount.description: The gross amount of the transaction.

gross_asset.description: The gross asset of the transaction.

invoice_number.description: The ID of the invoice for the payment.

custom.description: A free-text field that is entered by the merchant during checkout.

transaction_info_list.description: An array of transactions for which disputes were created.

start_time.name: start_time
start_time.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a creation date and time. The start time must be within the last 180 days. Value is in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameters.

disputed_transaction_id.name: disputed_transaction_id
disputed_transaction_id.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a transaction, by ID.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameter.

page_size.name: page_size
page_size.description: Limits the number of disputes in the response to this value.

next_page_token.name: next_page_token
next_page_token.description: The token that describes the next page of results to fetch. The list disputes call returns this token in the HATEOAS links in the response.

dispute_state.name: dispute_state
dispute_state.description: Filters the disputes in the response by a state. Separate multiple values with a comma (`,`). When you specify more than one dispute_state, the response lists disputes that belong to any of the specified dispute_state.

x-enumDescriptions.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_ACTION dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_OTHER_PARTY_ACTION dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the UNDER_PAYPAL_REVIEW dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the RESOLVED dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the OPEN_INQUIRIES dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the APPEALABLE dispute state.

update_time_before.name: update_time_before
update_time_before.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`. update_time_before must be within the last 180 days and the default is the current time.

update_time_after.name: update_time_after
update_time_after.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`. update_time_after must be within the last 180 days and the default is the maximum time (180 days) supported.

id.name: id
id.description: The ID of the dispute for which to provide the supporting information.
